## Why did we "domesticate" cat ?

::: {style="font-size: 50%;"}

:::{.incremental}

- Today's domesticates, initially farm animals, contrast with the unique domestication path of cats.
- Cats formed a commensal relationship with humans in the Fertile Crescent, attracted by early farmers' settlements combating rodent pests.
:::


![](images/image13.png)
<https://www.pnas.org/doi/epdf/10.1073/pnas.0901586106>

![](images/image12.png)

:::{.incremental}

Late Neolithic NE cats exhibited distinct stable isotope compositions and dietary patterns compared to contemporary humans, dogs, and Roman Period cats in farmland.

:::


<https://www.pnas.org/doi/epdf/10.1073/pnas.1918884117>

:::



## Recent domestication ?

![](images/image9.png)


::: {style="font-size: 50%;"}
<https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-017-0139>
::: 

## Brief conclusion

:::{.incremental}

- The domestication history of *Felis catus* is intricate and not fully understood today.
- There is a consensus about a commensal history.
- The domestic cat's characteristics are not very different from its wild ancestor.
:::

## Conclusion


::: {style="font-size: 70%;"}
:::{.incremental}

- No clear relationships between prey biomass and domestic cat abundance

- No evidence of any population declines of prey because of domestic cat depredation in continental context

- Evidences of possible compensatory effect

- Mainly non threatened species depredated by domestic cats

- Extremely context dependent, for example effect of the forest ! 

- BUT, sub-lethal effect exists ...

- BUT, no evidence for the moment but existing studies still lacking of robustness !

:::
:::
